awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Friction Stir Processing of Cast Metal Matrix Nanocomposites
awd_abstract_narration:
Incorporation of nanoparticles into light metals, forming metal matrix nanocomposites, can lead to significantly enhanced properties to generate tremendous impacts in the automotive, aerospace, and other industries that demand lightweight structural components in order to achieve high energy efficiency, which also means less air pollution.  However, it is very difficult to achieve a good dispersion and capture of nanoparticles during solidification of metals. Effective nanoparticle incorporation into high temperature metal melts also presents a severe problem. Friction stir processing can serve as a powerful tool to disperse nanoparticles in the lightweight metal matrix nanocomposites fabricated by semi-solid processing at a relatively low temperature. This award supports fundamental research to provide knowledge needed to create a simple, novel and scalable manufacturing technology to drive metal matrix nanocomposites toward widespread applications. The research will attract, retain, and engage students from under-represented group. K-12 students/teachers and industry partners will be exposed to the new technology. Interdisciplinary curriculum materials will be developed to train graduate and undergraduate students.

The objectives of this collaborative project are to (1) significantly advance the fundamental understanding of how friction stir processing interacts with nanoparticles in lightweight metal matrix nanocomposites, fabricated by semi-solid casting route, through a systematic experimental study on the nanoparticle movements and dispersion inside the grains during processing, and (2) understand the processing-microstructure-properties relations by investigating the effects of nanoparticle size and morphology, nanoparticle loading, and processing parameters on the micro/nano-structural evolution and the resultant mechanical properties of the nanocomposites. The metal matrix nanocomposites for the experimental study will be fabricated through a combination of semi-solid casting and friction stir processing to effectively incorporate nanoparticles in semi-solid state at a relatively-low temperature and disperse nanoparticles and refine microstructures in solid state to achieve superior properties. Through micro/nano materials analysis tools, this study will characterize micro/nano-structures, nanoparticle incorporation and distribution in alloys at semi-solid state and the nanoparticle dispersion by friction stir processing in metal matrix nanocomposites. Tensile and hardness (macro, micro, and nano) tests will be conducted to characterize the mechanical properties of the nanocomposites before and after friction stir processing.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Incorporation of nanoparticles (NPs) into metals can lead to significantly enhanced chemical, physical, and mechanical properties. The potential of lightweight metal matrix nanocomposites (MMNCs) cannot be fully developed for widespread industrial applications unless high performance structural components can be mass manufactured. Moreover, high quality MMNC parts cannot be produced unless NPs can be dispersed and distributed uniformly in metal matrix. However, it is very difficult to achieve a good dispersion and capture of NPs during solidification of metals. Effective nanoparticle incorporation into high temperature metal melts also presents a problem due to the burning/oxidation (reaction) issues of nanoparticles at high temperatures and their tendency to float on the surface of melt. Semi-solid slurries with high and controllable viscosity could be advantageous for MMNC processing as NPs can be added and kept in the semi-solid matrix without floating or burning during simple mechanical mixing. Preliminary study shows that nanoparticle incorporation at semi-solid state has great potential for scalable mass production. However, the NPs form micro clusters after the semi-solid mixing. Friction Stir Processing (FSP) provides a powerful tool to disperse nanoparticles in the MMNCs fabricated by the semi-solid processing.

Intellectual Merit: This project significantly advanced the fundamental understanding of how FSP interacts with NPs in MMNCs fabricated by semi-solid casting route and through surface modification. Hierarchically structured composites were fabricated with micron-size B4C and nano-size Y2O3. These composites have excellent combination of strength-ductility-stiffness with a marked improvement of the modulus (about 92%). Strength values close to 350 MPa and ductility values up to 30% were achieved in these MMNCs. This project significantly advanced the fundamental understanding of how nanoparticles are critical to enhancing ductility in high strength magnesium composites. The activation of non-basal slip activity in NP reinforced composites leads to high work hardening.

Broader Impacts: MMNCs offer superior performance, with striking potential to generate tremendous impacts in the automotive, aerospace, and other industries that demand lightweight structural components in order to achieve high energy efficiency. The automotive industry, in particular, is under constant pressure to achieve higher fuel efficiency, which also means less air pollution. The widespread use of MMNCs depends on if they can be fabricated cost-effectively, such as by casting and welding/processing. This study demonstrated excellent processability of as-cast MMNCs by FSP. A book titled "Metallurgy and Design of Alloys with Hierarchical Microstructures" was published in June 2017 with the PI as a co-author. Chapter 7 in the book is on magnesium alloys. This NSF supported work on magnesium alloys has helped the PI to develop new concepts. For example, concepts of microstructural efficiency and alloying efficiency have been introduced. These concepts allow discussion of pathways for development of hierarchical microstructure in cost-effective magnesium alloys. Appropriate selection of alloying elements can promote synergy between microstructural and alloying efficiency. The current research on incorporation of nanoparticles is an attempt to validate such microstructural design approach.


Last Modified: 10/01/2018
Modified by: Rajiv S Mishra

    Rajiv Mishra

    Microstructural analysis
  • (a) Engineering stress-strain curve for constant Y2O3 volume fraction, (b) engineering stress-strain curve for constant B4C volume fraction, and (c, d) engineering stress-strain curve of runs with different FSP parameters.
    Rajiv Mishra
    Copyrighted
    Rajiv S Mishra
